challenges.title: Introduction to Basic CSS
description:
Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) tell the browser how to display the text and other content that you write in HTML.

Note that CSS is case-sensitive so be careful with your capitalization.

CSS has been adopted by all major browsers and allows you to control:
  • color
  • fonts
  • positioning
  • spacing
  • sizing
  • decorations
  • transitions

There are three main ways to apply CSS styling. You can apply inline styles directly to HTML elements with the style attribute. Or you can place CSS rules within style tags in an HTML document. Finally, you can write CSS rules in an external style sheet, then reference that file in the HTML document. Even though the first two options have their uses, most developers prefer external style sheets because they keep the styles separate from the HTML elements. This improves the readability and reusability of your code.
In this section, you'll see how adding CSS styles to the elements of your FriendsPhotoApp can change it from simple text to something more.

challenges.title: Change the Color of Text
description: Now let's change the color of some of our text.
We can do this by changing the style of your h1 element.
The CSS property that is responsible for the color of an element's text is the "color" property.
Here's how you would set your h1 element's text color property to a value of blue:
<h1 style="color: blue;">FriendsPhotoApp</h1>
Note that it is a good practice to end inline style declarations with a semicolon ;.
<hr>
Change your h1 element's style so that its text color is red.
challengeSeed: Do I not destroy my enemies when I make them my friends? -- Abraham Lincoln
tests: assert($("h1").css("color") === "rgb(255, 0, 0)", 'message: Your h1 element should be red.');
assert(code.match(/\s*FriendsPhotoApp\s*<\/h1>/),' message: Your style declaration should end with a ; .');

challenges.title: Use CSS Selectors to Style Elements
description: When you entered <h1 style="color: red;">FriendsPhotoApp</h1>, you were giving that individual h1 element an inline style.
That's not a good way to add style to an element, so here's a better way.
At the top of your code, create a style element like this:

<style>
</style>
Inside that style element, you can create a CSS selector for all h1 elements. For example, if you wanted all h1 elements to be red, your style element would look like this:

<style>
  h1 {
    color: red;
  }
</style>

Note that it's important to have both opening and closing curly braces ({ and }) around the style declarations. You also need to make sure all your CSS is between the opening and closing style tags. Finally, be sure to add the semicolon to the end of each of your styles declarations.
<hr>
Delete your h1 element's style attribute and instead create a CSS style element. Add the necessary CSS to turn all h1 elements blue.
challengeSeed: Do I not destroy my enemies when I make them my friends? -- Abraham Lincoln
tests: assert(!$("h1").attr("style"), 'message: Remove the style attribute from your h1 element.');
assert($("style") && $("style").length > 1, 'message: Create a style element.');
assert($("h1").css("color") === "rgb(0, 0, 255)", 'message: Your h1 element should be blue.');
assert(code.match(/h1\s*\{\s*color\s*:.*;\s*\}/g), 'message: Ensure that your stylesheet h1 declaration is valid with a semicolon and closing brace.');
assert(code.match(/<\/style>/g) && code.match(/<\/style>/g).length === (code.match(//g) || []).length, 'message: Make sure all your style elements are valid and have a closing tag.');

challenges.title: Use a CSS Class to Style an Element
description: Classes are reusable styles that can be added to HTML elements.

Here's an example CSS class declaration that might be used for some introductory text. Note that the class name of "preface" is not special. It is up to you to choose any class name you would like that describes the purpose of the style.

<style>
  .preface {
    color: blue;
  }
</style>
You can see that we've created a CSS class called preface within the <style> tag.
You can apply a class to an HTML element like this:
<h1 class="preface">FriendsPhotoApp</h1>
Note that in your CSS style element, classes should start with a period. In your HTML elements' class declarations, classes should not start with a period.
<hr>
Inside your style element, change the h1 selector to .intro and update the color's value from blue to red.
Give your h1 element the class attribute with a value of 'intro'.

tests: assert($("h1").css("color") === "rgb(255, 0, 0)", 'message: Your h1 element should be red.');
assert($("h1").hasClass("intro"), 'message: Your h1 element should have the class intro.');
assert(code.match(/\.intro\s*\{\s*color\s*:\s*red;\s*\}/g), 'message: Your stylesheet should declare a intro class and have its color set to red.');
assert($("h1").attr("style") === undefined, 'message: Do not use inline style declarations like style="color: red" in your h1 element.');

  font-weight: 100;
}
You can also use the values of bold and normal as shortcuts instead of giving a numeric weight.

challenges.title: Use an id Attribute to Style an Element
description: You already know about using element selectors and class selectors. Id selectors are the third and final type of simple selectors you can use in CSS.

An id is not reusable and should only be applied to one element. An id also has a higher specificity (importance) than a class so if both are applied to the same element and have conflicting styles, the styles of the id will be applied.
Here's an example of how you can take your element with the id attribute of friends-photo-main and give it the background color of green. In your style element:

}
Note that inside your style element, you always reference classes by putting a . in front of their names. You always reference ids by putting a # in front of their names.

challenges.title: Size Your Images
description: You have already learned a lot about CSS. You have learned something about styling text. And you have learned about simple selectors like element, class, and id selectors. Next up we will start looking at the basics of layout. Layout is how you control where elements appear on the page.

Changing the size of an element affects the layout because a smaller element takes up less space on the page. In the next few lessons it's important for you to starting noticing how much space elements take up.
CSS has a property called width that controls an element's width. Just like with fonts, we'll use px (pixels) to specify the image's width.
For example, if we wanted to create a CSS style for the element with id heading-image that gave the element a width of 500 pixels, we'd use:

<style>
  #heading-image {
    width: 500px;
  }
</style>
<hr>

challenges.title: Adjust the Padding of an Element
description: Now let's put our Friends Photo App away and learn more about some types of styling that affect layout.
You may have already noticed this, but some HTML elements are boxes and each box takes up some horizontal and vertical space on the page, also known as the width and height of the element.
Each box in the CSS box model is made up of four parts. We already know what content is from the the Introduction to HTML section. The other three parts of the box are: padding, margin, and border.
The margin and the padding are invisible. If a border is specified you can usually see it.
An element's padding controls the amount of space between the element's content and the element's border. Look at the diagram to make sure you understand this.

Compare the above diagram with our code. We can see that the blue box and the red box are nested within the yellow box. Note that the red box has more padding than the blue box. Also note the border is black and surrounds each box.
When you increase the blue box's padding, it will increase the distance between the content "lorem ipsum" and the border around the content.
<hr>
Change the padding of your blue box to match that of your red box.

When you increase the blue box's margin, it will increase the distance between its border and surrounding elements.
